description: I started my career as a public safety dispatcher just two years after the Rodney King riots left a gaping wound on all of America, in the same county that acquitted the four officers, determined to be part of the solution. Am I angry that 26 years into my career, this type of treatment of my fellow human beings is still going on? I am heartbroken for the family of George...
text:
I started my career as a public safety dispatcher just two years after the
Rodney King riots left a gaping wound on all of America, in the same county
that acquitted the four officers, determined to be part of the solution. Am I
angry that 26 years into my career, this type of treatment of my fellow human
beings is still going on? Hell, yes. I understand that anger.

But I am now, all these years later, more disappointed and heartbroken that we
are still having this conversation (if you ever got the "I'm disappointed in
you" speech from a parent, you'll know that phrase, a lot of times, was worse
than getting yelled at). I'm disappointed that we, as a nation and as law
enforcement, have not done better. I'm disappointed that "we" in law
enforcement have not weeded out those individuals who still see colors when
they enforce the law. I'm disappointed that we are still having people of
color unjustly dying at the hands of these evil people when the vast majority
of us just want to make our corner of the world a little better place.

I am heartbroken for the family of George Floyd and any other family that has
had to go through this. I am heartbroken that officers are being injured
because of the actions of others like them who should have done better. I'm
heartbroken that 26 years later, nothing has changed.

I'm very close retirement and while I may have made a difference in my little
pond, the seas are rising up and threatening to drown us all because we have
failed. And I'm heartbroken and disappointed in that failure.

Step up and be the voices for change from within our law enforcement
organizations. Lead by example. Be part of the solution.

Marlana Biesecker, Ventura

title: Letter: Law enforcement should be part of solution
html:
I started my career as a public safety dispatcher just two years after the Rodney King riots left a gaping wound on all of America, in the same county that acquitted the four officers, determined to be part of the solution. Am I angry that 26 years into my career, this type of treatment of my fellow human beings is still going on? Hell, yes. I understand that anger.

But I am now, all these years later, more disappointed and heartbroken that we are still having this conversation (if you ever got the "I'm disappointed in you" speech from a parent, you'll know that phrase, a lot of times, was worse than getting yelled at). I'm disappointed that we, as a nation and as law enforcement, have not done better. I'm disappointed that "we" in law enforcement have not weeded out those individuals who still see colors when they enforce the law. I'm disappointed that we are still having people of color unjustly dying at the hands of these evil people when the vast majority of us just want to make our corner of the world a little better place.

I am heartbroken for the family of George Floyd and any other family that has had to go through this. I am heartbroken that officers are being injured because of the actions of others like them who should have done better. I'm heartbroken that 26 years later, nothing has changed.

I'm very close retirement and while I may have made a difference in my little pond, the seas are rising up and threatening to drown us all because we have failed. And I'm heartbroken and disappointed in that failure.

Step up and be the voices for change from within our law enforcement organizations. Lead by example. Be part of the solution.

Marlana Biesecker, Ventura
